publicationStmt.publisher: The Characters that shaped the Silk Road - A Database and Digital Paleography of Tarim

seg.seg: ... he sees the spirit, which is not bound by (...) things, as the cause to the redemption of the sorrows, [and] he sees [it] as the way to the nirvāṇa. In this way the ... of the filth ...
... (being) arising through causes; he sees them extinguishing in the non-existence of the causes, without substance [and] empty. Thereupon the whole world ... step (by step)
... looking after (= anupaśya) is the basis of consciousness (= smṛtyupasthāna). Looking after the law among the laws [is done] by the basis of consciousness. The four noble (truths?) ...
... the eightfold noble path, leading to the suppression of sorrow, is the truth of the noble ones. || || This is the second pratīsamutpāda.
... The rūpaskandha is to be looked at in this way: [it is] like an ant hill (lit. 'ant nest'). As the ants enter into [their] hill, so the rūpaskandha ...
... pricks, sorrow through ... here the nature of ignorance is to be observed. || If the skandha of sense (= vedānāskandha) pricked, ...

... [and] with one hand he drew this poisoned arrow (i.e., the vedānāskandha) out of it, [and] with the other (lit. second) hand he smeared medicine on it and made him quiet – this then is immeasurable sorrow.
Mit der (einen) Hand möge er ihm diesen Pfeil ... herausziehen, mit der anderen Hand möge er ihm Heilmittel aufschmieren [und] ihn zur Ruhe bringen.
With (one) hand he shall pull the arrow out of him ...., with the other hand he shall smear medicine on him [and] get him to rest.
... Like the light of the moon and the stars in a large lake on a dark night: as often as one touches in the water in order to seize it, so often one sees (that it is an illusion).
[Just] as the light of the moon and the stars in a large lake on a dark night: as often as one touches in the water in order to seize it, so often one sees (that it is an illusion).
... Like if a blind man wove a garment [and], being helplessly thrown, it burnt in the homely (lit. maternal) hearth,
... (just like that) ... burn in the hearth of impermanence. He sees even the exertions as empty and as deceit. He sees perception (= vijñāna) as something volatile, glowing now here then there ...
... Thus I have pervaded divine and human forms in this string of deed[s], thus [also] hell, animal and preta [forms]. Just as one sees one's own cycle of form[s], ...
... I made rain the down-pour of sense (= vedānā) for myself and for others. || The sign [is] the attachment like [to] a heap of jewels ... the four ornaments ...

p.note: b3-6 have a parallel in a1-6;
"Written in small ductus, and very clearly preserved, it is the right edge, and probably half, of a large ... manuscript" (60).
snai-āñm: literally 'without self', here 'without substance' after 66
first palkalyñe: pa added under line
rūpaṣṣe ātse: lit. 'the shoulder of the rūpa', where ātse (for āntse is a literal rendering of Skt. skandha 'shoulder; skandha (an element)'.
nāskoy: argues for 'spin', but 'weave', also attested for the TA equivalent of this verb, fits definitely better here.
enersäṅk: if Malzahn's 'hilflos' (215-216) is correct, it must refer to the garment, which seems to be the subject of the following clause.

after a1, we can complete from approximately the 12th akṣara of this line onwards koy w· or koy l·. This may be a further optative, e.g. tākoy '[if] he were'. Unfortunately, this fragmentary restoration is followed by a considerable lacuna of unknown length.
nrai: with 83, the akṣara looks rather like trai.
after a3, the left part of this line must have contained ssont • || saṃsāräntse svabhāpsa (82).
ṣotri eṅkalyñe: this expression returns in b5.

list.item: a1 ... he sees the spirit, which is not bound by (...) things, as the cause to the redemption of the sorrows, [and] he sees [it] as the way to the nirvāṇa. In this way the ... of the filth ... a2 ... (being) arising through causes; he sees them extinguishing in the non-existence of the causes, without substance [and] empty. Thereupon the whole world ... step (by step) a3 ... looking after (= anupaśya) is the basis of consciousness (= smṛtyupasthāna). Looking after the law among the laws [is done] by the basis of consciousness. The four noble (truths?) ... a4 ... the eightfold noble path, leading to the suppression of sorrow, is the truth of the noble ones. || || This is the second pratīsamutpāda. a5 ... The rūpaskandha is to be looked at in this way: [it is] like an ant hill (lit. 'ant nest'). As the ants enter into [their] hill, so the rūpaskandha ... a6 ... pricks, sorrow through ... here the nature of ignorance is to be observed. || If the skandha of sense (= vedānāskandha) pricked, ... b1 ... [and] with one hand he drew this poisoned arrow (i.e., the vedānāskandha) out of it, [and] with the other (lit. second) hand he smeared medicine on it and made him quiet – this then is immeasurable sorrow. b2 ... Like the light of the moon and the stars in a large lake on a dark night: as often as one touches in the water in order to seize it, so often one sees (that it is an illusion). b3 ... Like if a blind man wove a garment [and], being helplessly thrown, it burnt in the homely (lit. maternal) hearth, b4 ... (just like that) ... burn in the hearth of impermanence. He sees even the exertions as empty and as deceit. He sees perception (= vijñāna) as something volatile, glowing now here then there ... b5 ... Thus I have pervaded divine and human forms in this string of deed[s], thus [also] hell, animal and preta [forms]. Just as one sees one's own cycle of form[s], ... b6 ... I made rain the down-pour of sense (= vedānā) for myself and for others. || The sign [is] the attachment like [to] a heap of jewels ... the four ornaments ...

a1 /// (mā wänta)rw(a)mpa rittoṣ palsko läklentameṃ tsälpātsiś ṣarm lkāṣṣäṃ • nervāṇäṣṣai ytāri lkāṣṣäṃ • te-yäknesa kr(ā)ke(t)s(e) a2 /// (nesamane ṣä)rmanasa tseṅkemane • ṣärmanmaṃts mā tatākarne kesemane lkāṣṣän-me • snai-āñm aikarona • tumeṃ po śaiṣṣe yke a3 (postäṃ) /// ompostäṃ palkalyñe imentse śmoñña • ce pelaiknentane pelaikne omṣostäṃ palkalyñe imentse śmoññaisa • śtwāra klyo- a4 /// läklentse prutkālyñene ynūca oktatsa klyomña ytārye klyomoṃts empreṃtsäññe • || || se wete pratītyasamutpat a5 /// (rū)paṣṣe ātse taisa lkāṣṣälle mäkte wärmīya lesto • mäkte warmi lestaine yänmaskeṃ • taisa rūpaṣṣe ātse a6 /// -k tsāknaṃ läkle – – ·entsa tane aknātsaññeṃtse ṣañäññe lkāṣṣälle || warpalyñaṣṣe āntse tsaknoy|tsakno|(y) b1 /// (ṣe)me ṣarsa ceṃ prer(esa wsecce salkoy-ne|sä)lkoy-ne • wace ṣarsa (sāṃ)tkenta laupoy-ne āñu yamī-ne • su ṅke aparimāṃ läkl(e) b2 /// (mä)kte orocce lyamne orkamotsai yaṣine meñantse ściriṃts läkutsauña|läktsauña kos ālpaṃ warne entwe eṅktsi|eṅtsi tot b3 /// (l)k(ā)ṣṣäṃ mäkte tärrek eṅkwe|eṅwe yesti nāskoy enersäṅk ṣaläskemane tuk mataryai śolyine päst tsśīträ b4 /// (mā) ṣ(e)k(a)ññeṣṣai śoline tsäksenträ • skeyeṃ rano aikareṃ tserekwa lkāṣṣäṃ || vijñāṃ pälyca-pälyc|pälyca-pälycä taisa lkāṣṣäṃ tane tamne tsaksemane b5 /// (t)aisa ñiś yāmorṣṣe śerkne ñäkcīyana śāmñana rūpanma sätkasamai taisa nrai lwāsa preteṣṣana • mäkte ṣañ rūpaṣṣe serke lkāṣṣäṃ b6 /// s·ä warpalyñeṣṣeṃ praściye swāsäṣṣawa ṣañ śle alyeṅkäṃts || ṣotri eṅkalyñe naumiyeṣṣe taupe ra śwarā-tsaiñenta|śwarā(-ts)ai|(ñenta)
b3-6 have a parallel in [[THT 153]] a1-6; [[THT 1440]]

Translations from [[Peyrot, ToSu]]
Lines Translation Pages
b2-3 [Just] as the light of the moon and the stars in a large lake on a dark night: as often as one touches in the water in order to seize it, so often one sees (that it is an illusion). 322

Translations from [[Schmidt KT 1974]]
Lines Translation Pages
b1 Mit der (einen) Hand möge er ihm diesen Pfeil ... herausziehen, mit der anderen Hand möge er ihm Heilmittel aufschmieren [und] ihn zur Ruhe bringen. 438


CHECK: British Library, Hoernle Coll No 149.22, Pratītyasamutpāda, Toch B 154, s.a. : Hartmann, Jens-Uwe und Wille, Klaus : Die nordturkistanischen Sanskrit-Handschriften der Sammlung Hoernle. in : Sanskrit-Texte aus dem buddhistischen Kanon : Neuentdeckungen und Neueditionen. 2.Folge. Göttingen 1992


Hannes: According to Malzahn 2010: 943, b1 should be restored as ceṃ prer(esa wsecce sa)lkoy-ne.



Translation according to [[Broomhead I]]: 66-67:

a1. He sees the spirit, which is not bound by things, as the cause of redemption from sorrows, [and] he sees it as the way to nirvāṇa. In this way the filth

a2. The 'being' ('coming into being') he sees as arising through causes. He sees them coming extinguished in 'non-existence'. Without substance, empty [and] thereupon the world immediately

a3. The 'looking towards' [is] smṛtyupasthāna. This anupaśya towards the law among the dharmas by means of smṛtyupasthāna. The four noble

a4. The eightfold noble path, which leads towards the annihilation of sorrow [and] pain [is] the truth of the noble path/āryas. That is the second pratītyasamutpāda.

a5. The rupaskandha is to be looked at [in] this way. [It is] like an ants' nest. [Just as] the ants enter [their] nest, [so] does the rupaskandha

a6. Sorrow pricks ...: By means of ... the characteristic of ignorance is to be observed. The vedānāskandha pricked ...

b1. Let him draw out this poisoned arrow with one hand, and with the other hand let him smear on the remedies [and] let him make it quiet. That [is] now an immeasurable sorrow

b2. [Just] as in a great lake on a dark night, so long as th elight of the moon and stars is reflected in the water, just so long then is [it] to be grasped.

b3. [He] sees like a blind man who might be washing, [and] inadvertently [and carelessly] throwing this away [so that] it might [easily] burn in his own (metrnal) hearth.

b4. It burns in the hearth-[fire] of inconstancy [and] he sees even the 'exertions' as being falsehood and deceit. He sees perception moving thus [and] burning here and there fleeting

b5. Even so I have developed in this chain of deeds, divine, human, hellish, animal [and] preta forms. [Just] as he sees his own chain of forms.

b6. I ordered the vedāna down-pour for myself [and] for others. The sign [of this] is the 'clinging' (attachment) like a jewel-mine. Fourfold [are] the ornaments ...


NOTES (p. 67):

a5. wärmīya, warmi are probably 'ant' cf. [[W 3]]: a5 [!!] wärmiye tsarātre (under tsarātre in index) and cf. wärmiye in index. lesto, O. lestai probably means 'nest', cf. also letse 'abode, dwelling' in index.

b3. yesti is hapax legomenon, but probably menas 'washing' as it is seen here with the verb NĀSK-.
"Written in small ductus, and very clearly preserved, it is the right edge, and probably half, of a large ... manuscript" ([[Broomhead I]]: 60).

a2. snai-āñm: literally 'without self', here 'without substance' after [[Broomhead I]]: 66

a3. omṣostäṃ: for ompostäṃ

a3. first palkalyñe: pa added under line

a4. wete: for wate.

a4. rūpaṣṣe ātse: lit. 'the shoulder of the rūpa', where ātse (for āntse is a literal rendering of Skt. skandha 'shoulder; skandha (an element)'.

a6. warpalyñaṣṣe: for warpalyñeṣṣe.

b3. nāskoy: [[Malzahn 2004]] argues for 'spin', but 'weave', also attested for the TA equivalent of this verb, fits definitely better here.

b3. enersäṅk: if Malzahn's 'hilflos' ([[Malzahn 2004]]: 215-216) is correct, it must refer to the garment, which seems to be the subject of the following clause.

b4. after [[THT 153]] a1, we can complete from approximately the 12th akṣara of this line onwards koy w· or koy l·. This may be a further optative, e.g. tākoy '[if] he were'. Unfortunately, this fragmentary restoration is followed by a considerable lacuna of unknown length.

b5. nrai: with [[TochSprR(B) II]]: 83, the akṣara looks rather like trai.

b5. after [[THT 153]] a3, the left part of this line must have contained ssont • || saṃsāräntse svabhāpsa ([[TochSprR(B) II]]: 82).

b6. ṣotri eṅkalyñe: this expression returns in [[THT 153]] b5.

[[IDP]]: IOL Toch 4; [[THT|TITUS]]: THT 154.

Edition: [[TochSprR(B) II]]: 83; [[Broomhead I]]: 60-61, 66-67; [[Peyrot 2007]]: №4.

Complete translation: [[Broomhead I]]: 66-67.

Translation: a1 [[Thomas 1954]]: 754; a4 [[Adams, DoT]]: 418, [[Carling 2000]]: 246, [[Thomas 1983]]: 21; a5 [[Adams, DoT]]: 580, [[Thomas 1968]]: 228; a6 [[Thomas 1979b]]: 13; b1 [[Schmidt KT 1974]]: 438; b2 [[Peyrot 2010]]: 262, [[Carling 2000]]: 131, [[Thomas 1969]]: 244, [[Thomas 1969c]]: 201; b2-3 [[Carling 2000]]: 304; [[Peyrot, ToSu]]: 322; b3 [[Krause, WTG]]: 139; b3-4 [[Thomas 1968]]: 226, [[Malzahn 2004]]: 215; b4 [[Schmidt KT 1974]]: 20 n. 3; b5 [[Krause, WTG]]: 187; b6 [[Thomas 1979d]]: 156.

.

a1 /// -rw·mpa ritto_ṣ\ palsko _l_aklentameṃ ts_alpātsiśä\ ṣar_m\ lkā_ṣ_ṣ_aṃ • nervāṇäṣṣai ytāri lkā_ṣ_ṣ_aṃ • te-yäknesa kr·ke[·s·] a2 /// -rmanasa tseṅkemane • _ṣ_armanmaṃt_s\ mā tatākarne kesemane lkā_ṣ_ṣ_an-me • snai-āñ_mä\ aikarona • tumeṃ po śaiṣṣe yke a3 /// ompos_t_aṃ palkalyñe imentse śmoñña • ce pelaiknentane pelaikne omṣos_t_aṃ palkalyñe imentse śmoññaisa • śtwāra klyo- a4 /// [_l_a]k[l]entse prutkālyñene ynūca oktatsa klyomña ytārye klyomoṃt_s\ empreṃt_s_aññe • || || se wete pratītyasamutpa_t\ a5 /// – paṣṣe ātse taisa lkā_ṣ_ṣ_alle _m_akte wärmīya lesto • _m_akte warmi lestaine yänmaskeṃ • taisa rūpaṣṣe ātse a6 /// -_k[\] tsāknaṃ _l_akle (–) – ·[e]ntsa tane aknātsaññeṃtse ṣañäññe lkā_ṣ_ṣ_alle || warpalyñaṣṣe āntse tsakno b1 /// -[me] ṣarsa ceṃ prer· (–) – (–) [l]k[o]y-ne • wace ṣarsa – tkenta laupoy-ne āñu yamī-ne • su ṅke aparimāṃ _l_akl· b2 /// -kte orocce lyamne orkamotsai yaṣine meñantse ściriṃt_s\ _l_aktsauña ko_s\ ālpaṃ warne entwe eṅtsi to_t\ b3 /// ·k·_ṣ_ṣ_aṃ _m_akte _t_arre_k\ eṅwe yesti nāskoyä\ ener_s_aṅ_k\ ṣa_l_askemane tu_k\ mataryai śolyine _p_as_t\ tsśīt_r_a b4 /// [ṣ]·k·ññeṣṣai śoline t_s_aksent_r_a • skeyeṃ rano aikareṃ tserekwa lkā_ṣ_ṣ_aṃ || vijñāṃ _p_alyca-_p_alycä taisa lkā_ṣ_ṣ_aṃ tane tamne tsaksemane b5 /// ·aisa ñiś\ yāmorṣṣe śerkne ñäkcīyana śāmñana rūpanma _s_atkasamai taisa nrai lwāsa preteṣṣana • _m_akte ṣañä\ rūpaṣṣe serke lkā_ṣ_ṣ_aṃ b6 /// [s·]ä warpalyñeṣṣeṃ praściye swā_s_aṣṣawa ṣañä\ śle alyeṅ_k_aṃt_s\ || ṣotri eṅkalyñe naumiyeṣṣe taupe ra ś[w]arā·ai

div.p:
CHECK: British Library, Hoernle Coll No 149.22, Pratītyasamutpāda, Toch B 154, s.a. : Hartmann, Jens-Uwe und Wille, Klaus : Die nordturkistanischen Sanskrit-Handschriften der Sammlung Hoernle. in : Sanskrit-Texte aus dem buddhistischen Kanon : Neuentdeckungen und Neueditionen. 2.Folge. Göttingen 1992

Hannes: According to Malzahn 2010: 943, b1 should be restored as ceṃ prer(esa wsecce sa)lkoy-ne.

Translation according to <citedRange>66-67</citedRange></bibl>: </p><p>a1. He sees the spirit, which is not bound by things, as the cause of redemption from sorrows, [and] he sees it as the way to nirvāṇa. In this way the filth </p><p>a2. The 'being' ('coming into being') he sees as arising through causes. He sees them coming extinguished in 'non-existence'. Without substance, empty [and] thereupon the world immediately </p><p>a3. The 'looking towards' [is] smṛtyupasthāna. This anupaśya towards the law among the dharmas by means of smṛtyupasthāna. The four noble </p><p>a4. The eightfold noble path, which leads towards the annihilation of sorrow [and] pain [is] the truth of the noble path/āryas. That is the second pratītyasamutpāda. </p><p>a5. The rupaskandha is to be looked at [in] this way. [It is] like an ants' nest. [Just as] the ants enter [their] nest, [so] does the rupaskandha </p><p>a6. Sorrow pricks ...: By means of ... the characteristic of ignorance is to be observed. The vedānāskandha pricked ... </p><p>b1. Let him draw out this poisoned arrow with one hand, and with the other hand let him smear on the remedies [and] let him make it quiet. That [is] now an immeasurable sorrow </p><p>b2. [Just] as in a great lake on a dark night, so long as th elight of the moon and stars is reflected in the water, just so long then is [it] to be grasped. </p><p>b3. [He] sees like a blind man who might be washing, [and] inadvertently [and carelessly] throwing this away [so that] it might [easily] burn in his own (metrnal) hearth. </p><p>b4. It burns in the hearth-[fire] of inconstancy [and] he sees even the 'exertions' as being falsehood and deceit. He sees perception moving thus [and] burning here and there fleeting </p><p>b5. Even so I have developed in this chain of deeds, divine, human, hellish, animal [and] preta forms. [Just] as he sees his own chain of forms. </p><p>b6. I ordered the vedāna down-pour for myself [and] for others. The sign [of this] is the 'clinging' (attachment) like a jewel-mine. Fourfold [are] the ornaments ... </p><p><hi>NOTES</hi> (p. 67): </p><p><ref type="ms" target="__a5."/><hi>wärmīya</hi>, <hi>warmi</hi> are probably 'ant' cf. <ref type="ms" target="txt:m-w3"/>: a5 [!!] <hi>wärmiye tsarātre</hi> (under <hi>tsarātre</hi> in index) and cf. <hi>wärmiye</hi> in index. <hi>lesto</hi>, O. <hi> lestai</hi> probably means 'nest', cf. also <hi>letse</hi> 'abode, dwelling' in index.</p><p><ref type="ms" target="__b3."/><hi>yesti</hi> is hapax legomenon, but probably menas 'washing' as it is seen here with the verb NĀSK-.</p></project_comment>
